texts.text-1-2: Utah State Board of Education OER
texts.text-5-1: What does science look and feel like?
texts.text-5-2: If you’re reading this book, either as a student or a teacher, you’re going to be digging into the “practice” of science.
texts.text-5-3: Probably, someone, somewhere, has made you think about this before, and so you’ve probably already had a chance to imagine the possibilities.
texts.text-5-4: Who do you picture doing science?
texts.text-5-7:
Often when we ask people to imagine this, they draw or describe people
                with lab coats, people with crazy hair, beakers and flasks of weird looking liquids that are bubbling and
                frothing.
texts.text-5-9:
Let’s be honest: Some scientists do look like this, or they look like
                other stereotypes: people readied with their pocket protectors and calculators, figuring out how to
                launch a rocket into orbit.
texts.text-5-10:
Or maybe what comes to mind is a list of steps that you might have to
                check off for your science fair project to be judged; or, maybe a graph or data table with lots of
                numbers comes to mind.
texts.text-5-12: When you imagine graphs and tables, lab coats and calculators, is that what you love?
texts.text-5-13: If this describes you, that’s great.
texts.text-5-14: But if it doesn’t, and that’s probably true for many of us, then go ahead and dump that image of science.
texts.text-5-15: It’s useless because it isn’t you.
texts.text-5-16: Instead, picture yourself as a maker and doer of science.
texts.text-5-17: The fact is, we need scientists and citizens like you, whoever you are, because we need all of the ideas, perspectives, and creative thinkers.
texts.text-5-20: They dig in the dirt and chip at rocks.
texts.text-5-23:
They play with tubes and pipes in the aisles of a hardware
                store to see what kinds of sounds they can make with them.
texts.text-5-25: They count and measure and predict.
texts.text-5-26:
They stare at the rock faces in the mountains and imagine how
                those came to be.
texts.text-5-28: They draw and write and write and write some more.
texts.text-5-29: Scientists— and this includes all of us who do, use, apply, or think about science — don’t fit a certain stereotype.
texts.text-5-30: What really sets us apart as humans is not just that we know and do things, but that we wonder and make sense of our world.
texts.text-5-31: We do this in many ways, through painting, religion, music, culture, poetry, and, most especially, science.
texts.text-5-32: Science isn’t just a method or a collection of things we know.
texts.text-5-33: It’s a uniquely human practice of wondering about and creating explanations for the natural world around us.
texts.text-5-34: This ranges from the most fundamental building blocks of all matter to the widest expanse of space that contains it all.
texts.text-5-35: If you’ve ever wondered “When did time start?”, or “What is the smallest thing?”, or even just “What is color?”, or so many other endless
texts.text-6-0: questions then you’re already thinking with a scientific mind.
texts.text-6-3: But here is where we really have to be clear.
texts.text-6-4: Science isn’t just questions and explanations.
texts.text-6-5: Science is about a sense of wondering and the sense-making itself.
texts.text-6-6: We have to wonder and then really dig into the details of our surroundings.
texts.text-6-7: We have to get our hands dirty.
texts.text-6-8:
Here’s a good example: two young scientists under the presence of
                        the Courthouse Towers in Arches National Park.
texts.text-6-9:
We can be sure that they spent some amount of time in awe of the
                        giant sandstone walls,
texts.text-6-10:
but here in this photo they’re enthralled with the sand that’s
                        just been re-washed by recent rain.
texts.text-6-11:
There’s this giant formation of sandstone looming above these
                        kids in the desert,
texts.text-6-12: and they’re happily playing in the sand.
texts.text-7-0: How did that sand get there?
texts.text-7-2: Did the sand come from the rock or does the rock come from sand?
texts.text-7-4: How do you tell this story?
texts.text-7-7: How often is there a puddle in the desert?
texts.text-7-8: The sand is wet and fine;
texts.text-7-9: and it makes swirling, layered patterns on the solid stone.
texts.text-7-10: There are pits and pockets in the rock, like the one that these two scientists are sitting in, and the gritty sand and the cold water accumulate there.
texts.text-7-12: And then you might start to wonder: Does the sand fill in the hole to form more rock, or is the hole worn away because it became sand?
texts.text-7-15: And then you might wonder more about the giant formation in the background:
texts.text-7-16: It has the same colors as the sand, so has this been built up or is it being worn down?
texts.text-7-18: And if it's being built up by sand, how does it all get put together; and if it's being worn away then why does it make the patterns that we see in the rock?
texts.text-7-24: Just as there is science to be found in a puddle or a pit or a simple rock formation,
texts.text-7-25: there's science in a soap bubble, in a worm, in the spin of a dancer and in the structure of a bridge.
texts.text-7-26: But this thing we call "science" is only there if you're paying attention, asking questions, and imagining possibilities.
texts.text-7-27: You have to make the science by being the person who gathers information and evidence,
texts.text-7-28: who organizes and reasons with this,
texts.text-7-29: and who communicates it to others.
texts.text-7-30: Most of all, you get to wonder.
texts.text-7-31: Throughout all of the rest of this book and all of the rest of the science that you will ever do,
texts.text-7-32: wonder should be at the heart of it all.
texts.text-7-33: Whether you're a student or a teacher,
texts.text-7-34: this wonder is what will bring the sense-making of science to life and make it your own.
texts.text-8-1:
Science and Engineering Practices are what scientists do to investigate and
                explore natural phenomena.
texts.text-9-1:
Crosscutting Concepts are the tools that scientists use to make sense of
                natural phenomena.
texts.text-9-4:
Structures or events are often consistent and
                                repeated.
texts.text-9-6:
Over time, a system might stay the same or
                                become different, depending on a variety of factors.
texts.text-9-8:
Events have causes, sometimes simple, sometimes
                                multifaceted.
texts.text-9-10:
Different measures of size and time affect a
                                system’s structure, performance, and our ability to observe phenomena.
texts.text-9-12:
Tracking energy and matter flows into, out of,
                                and within systems helps one understand their system’s behavior.
texts.text-9-14:
A set of connected things or parts forming a
                                complex whole.
texts.text-9-16:
The way an object is shaped or structured
                                determines many of its properties and functions.
texts.text-10-0: What is involved in Engineering Design?
texts.text-10-1: Engineering is a creative process where each new version of a design is tested and then modified, based on what has been learned up to that point.
texts.text-10-2: This process includes a number of components:
texts.text-10-3: Identifying the problem and defining criteria and constraints.
texts.text-10-4: Generating ideas for how to solve the problem.
texts.text-10-5: Engineers use research, brainstorming, and collaboration with others to come up with ideas for solutions and designs.
texts.text-10-6: Use criteria and constraints to evaluate possible design solutions to identify the one(s) that best address these parameters for the problem in context.
texts.text-10-8: Using data collected, the engineer analyzes how well prototypes meet the given criteria and constraints.
texts.text-10-9: Suggest or make improvements to prototypes to optimize the design.
texts.text-10-10:
In the Science with Engineering Education (SEEd) Standards, specific
                engineering standards generally involve two types of tasks:
texts.text-10-11:
If the standard includes the idea of designing, then the design
                    process will contain components of defining the problem (along with identifying the criteria and
                    constraints), developing many possible solutions, and optimizing a solution (e.g., determining a best
                    solution for the situation based on the criteria and constraints, testing the solution, refining the
                    solution).
texts.text-10-12:
If the standard includes the idea of evaluating, then the design process will
                    contain components of defining the problem (along with identifying the criteria and constraints) and
                    optimizing a solution.
texts.text-10-13:
The idea of developing many possible solutions is not included because
                various solutions will be provided.
texts.text-10-14:
The idea of evaluating then means determining a best solution from the provided
                solutions for the situation based on meeting the criteria and constraints requirements.
texts.text-11-23: CHAPTER 3-Cycling of Matter in Earth’s Systems
texts.text-13-1: Strand 1: Characteristics and Interactions of Earth’s Systems
texts.text-13-8: Earth’s major systems are the geosphere (solid and molten rock, soil, and sediments),
texts.text-13-16: Image by Julius Silver, pixabay.com, CC0
texts.text-13-11: and the biosphere (living things, including humans).
texts.text-13-12: These systems interact in multiple ways.
texts.text-13-13: Weathering and erosion are examples of interactions between Earth’s systems.
texts.text-13-14: Some interactions cause landslides, earthquakes, and volcanic eruptions that impact humans and other organisms.
texts.text-13-15: Humans cannot eliminate natural hazards; solutions can be designed to reduce their impact.
texts.text-15-2: In the Pacific Ocean there is a pathway of active volcanoes with frequent earthquakes, called the Ring of Fire. The dots represent active volcanoes.

texts.text-17-5: In this chapter, you will be looking at different patterns we see in Earth’s Features.
texts.text-17-1: Analyze and interpret data to describe patterns of Earth’s features.
texts.text-17-2: Emphasize most earthquakes and volcanoes occur in bands that are often along the boundaries between continents and oceans while major mountain chains may be found inside continents or near their edges.
texts.text-17-3: Examples of data could include maps showing locations of mountains on continents and the ocean floor or the locations of volcanoes and earthquakes.
texts.text-17-8: Volcanoes are openings in the Earth’s crust that allow hot, melted rock (magma), ash, and gases to erupt outward.
texts.text-17-9: Volcanoes change the Earth’s surface in a short period of time.
texts.text-17-10: More than half of Earth’s surface is made up of volcanic rock.
texts.text-17-11: Volcanoes are evidence that we live on an active, changing planet.
texts.text-17-12: Do you know how a volcano forms?
texts.text-17-13: Far below Earth’s surface, temperatures are hot enough to melt rock.
texts.text-17-14: The melted rock comes out of cracks in the Earth’s crust, resulting in a volcano.
texts.text-17-15: Some eruptions pour out rivers of lava while other volcanoes have larger eruptions.
texts.text-17-16: Volcanoes can erupt underwater, forming huge ranges of volcanic mountains on the ocean floor.
texts.text-17-18:
Most earthquakes and volcanic eruptions take place along the edges of
                the Pacific Ocean (see image below).
texts.text-17-19:
The Earth’s crust is broken up into a series of massive sections
                called plates.
texts.text-17-20:
The movements of these plates can account for noticeable changes to the
                Earth, such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and the building of mountains.
texts.text-17-21: This section is adapted from information at:
texts.text-18-0: The many volcanoes and earthquakes along the Ring of Fire are caused by the amount of movement of tectonic plates in the area.
texts.text-18-1: Along the Ring of Fire, plates overlap.
texts.text-18-2: The magma near Earth’s surface creates volcanic activity.
texts.text-18-3: The border between the Pacific and North American Plates (Phenomenon image) is a transform boundary, where plates move sideways past one another.
texts.text-18-4: This type of boundary generates a large number of earthquakes as tension in Earth’s crust builds up and is released.
texts.text-18-5: Plates can also move away from each other within a continent.
texts.text-18-7: When this happens, the crust thins, breaks, and then splits apart.
texts.text-18-9: Earthquakes are waves of energy that pass through Earth caused by a sudden shift of tectonic plates along fault lines, a long crack in the surface of the Earth.
texts.text-18-10: Earthquakes can cause sudden changes that alter the Earth’s landscape dramatically.
texts.text-18-11: Tremendous forces under Earth’s surface build up pressure, which is released in waves along a fault.
texts.text-18-12: Portions of Earth’s crust move, creating waves.
texts.text-18-13: Some of the waves are surface waves because they travel along the surface of the Earth.
texts.text-18-14: Other waves, called body waves, travel through the Earth’s interior.
texts.text-18-15: In an earthquake, body waves are responsible for the sharp jolts.
texts.text-18-16: Surface waves are responsible for the
texts.text-19-0: Rolling motions that cause most of the damage.
texts.text-19-1: Earthquakes can create landforms on the Earth’s surface.
texts.text-19-2: Mountains can form during an earthquake as the edges of the tectonic plates push together.
texts.text-19-3: During an earthquake, a fault may slip deep underground and leave no evidence on the surface that an earthquake has occurred.
texts.text-19-4: Earthquakes in the ocean may cause a tsunami, a large ocean wave.
texts.text-19-6: In the oceans, plates move apart at mid-ocean ridges, causing volcanoes, creating openings for lava to rise upward, erupt, and cool.
texts.text-19-7: As more lava erupts and pushes the original seafloor outward, the seafloor spreads and forms new oceanic crust.
texts.text-19-8: This is why there is a mountain range running through the oceans.
texts.text-19-9: The plates pulling apart cause earthquakes.
texts.text-19-10: Most mid-ocean ridges are located deep below the sea.
texts.text-19-11: The island of Iceland sits right on the Mid-Atlantic ridge.
texts.text-19-12: Mid Atlantic Ridge by Mangwanani, public domain
texts.text-19-13: The rift valley in Iceland is part of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge.

texts.text-25-1:
Use mathematics and computational thinking to compare the quantity of saltwater and freshwater in various
                reservoirs to provide evidence for the distribution of water on Earth.
texts.text-25-2: Emphasize reservoirs such as oceans, lakes, rivers, glaciers, groundwater, and polar ice caps.
texts.text-25-3:
Examples of using mathematics and computational thinking could include measuring, estimating, graphing,
                or finding percentages of quantities.
texts.text-25-5: In this section, focus on comparing the quantity of saltwater with freshwater found on the Earth.
texts.text-25-7: Earth's water is (almost) everywhere: above the Earth in the air and clouds (atmosphere),
texts.text-25-8: on the surface of the Earth in rivers, oceans, ice (hydrosphere),
texts.text-25-9: plants, in living organisms (biosphere), and inside the Earth (geosphere).
texts.text-25-10: This section is adapted from information at:
texts.text-26-0: Here is a chart showing the distribution of water on Earth.
texts.text-26-1: In the first column, notice that 2.5% of Earth's water is freshwater - the amount needed for life to survive.
texts.text-26-2: The middle column shows the breakdown of freshwater. Almost all of it is found in ice and in the ground.
texts.text-26-3: Only a little more than 1.2% of all freshwater is surface water, which provides most of life's needs.
texts.text-26-4: The right column shows the breakdown of surface freshwater.
texts.text-26-5: Most of the surface freshwater is found in ice, and another 20.9% is found in lakes.
texts.text-26-6: Rivers make up 0.49% of surface freshwater.
texts.text-26-7: Although rivers account for only a small amount of freshwater, rivers are the source of most usable water.
texts.text-26-26: How Much Water is There On, In, and Above the Earth?
texts.text-26-27: The Earth is a watery place.
texts.text-26-28: But just how much water exists on our planet?
texts.text-26-29:
About 71 percent of the Earth's surface is covered with water, and the
                oceans hold about 96 percent of all Earth's water.
texts.text-27-0: Air (as water vapor), rivers and lakes, icecaps and glaciers, the ground (as soil moisture and in aquifers).
texts.text-27-2:
Even though you may only notice water on the Earth's surface, more
                freshwater is stored in the ground than there is in liquid form on the surface.
texts.text-27-3:
In fact, some of the water you see flowing in rivers comes from water
                seeping into Earth's surface to become groundwater.
texts.text-27-4:
Water from precipitation continually seeps into the ground to fill
                aquifers (underground reservoirs), while at the same time water in the ground continually fills rivers
                through seepage.
texts.text-27-5: Humans make use of both surface water and groundwater.
texts.text-27-6:
In the United States in 2010, we used about 275 billion gallons (1,041
                billion liters) of surface water per day and about 79.3 billion gallons (300.2 billion liters) of
                groundwater per day.
texts.text-27-7:
Although surface water is used more often to supply drinking water and
                to irrigate crops, groundwater is vital because it fills rivers and lakes and provides water for people
                in places where water is scarce, such as in desert towns of the western United States.

texts.sectioneli5-0-0: This is a science book for kids in 5th grade living in Utah. It follows special rules called SEEd Standards, which are like guidelines to help everyone learn the same cool science stuff! Think of it as a fun guide to explore science in nature and the world around you!
texts.sectioneli5-1-0: This is a book for kids who are in 5th grade, which is a year you go through in school. It was made especially for kids in Utah and has lots of fun things to learn about. It's like a guide to help teachers know what to teach you this year!
texts.sectioneli5-2-0: This is the cover of a 5th grade science book. It shows a lot of colorful flowers under a bright sun, which might mean we're going to learn about how plants grow or what happens in nature. It's made for kids in Utah, so everyone there will be learning the same things about science.
texts.sectioneli5-3-1: The CK-12 Foundation is a group that helps make science textbooks for students like you. They want to make sure everyone can get learning materials without paying a lot of money. The picture shows this is for 5th-grade science, which means it's for learning about fun science stuff like plants and nature!
texts.sectioneli5-5-0:
Science is like playing detective! It's about asking questions about the world, like 'Why is the sky blue?' or 'How do plants grow?' Imagine someone who loves to find answers, even if they're not wearing a lab coat. 

Scientists can be anyone who likes exploring, trying things out, and thinking hard about why things happen. So if you like to ask questions and figure out puzzles, you're like a scientist too!
texts.sectioneli5-5-1: When people think about scientists, they might picture people in white coats with crazy hair working in labs with bubbling liquids and explosions. Sometimes, they also think of scientists using calculators and launching rockets. But science isn't just about these ideas. It's about asking questions, being curious, and everyone can be a scientist by exploring and wondering about the world.
texts.sectioneli5-5-2: When you think of science, you might imagine people in lab coats or using calculators. But if that doesn't sound like you, don't worry! Science isn't just about those things. It's about being curious and finding out how the world works, in your own way. We need different people with different ideas to do science, and that includes you!
texts.sectioneli5-5-3: Scientists don't just wear lab coats and work in labs. They explore nature, like walking in the woods and looking at rocks. They use things like microscopes to see tiny details. Sometimes, they play with everyday things to see what happens. They enjoy using their imagination and thinking about big questions, like how mountains were made. Scientists also love drawing, writing, and even dancing as they learn new things. Science is about being curious and discovering exciting things about the world!
texts.sectioneli5-5-4: Science is like being a big detective for everything around us. It's not just wearing a lab coat or mixing potions. Anyone can be a scientist because it's about asking questions like 'Why is the sky blue?' or 'What makes rain?' We use different ways, like drawing, writing, or music, to explore and discover. So every time you wonder about how things work, you're doing science! It's all about curiosity and trying to understand the amazing world we live in.
texts.sectioneli5-6-0: Science is like being super curious about everything. It's not just about asking questions but also about exploring and figuring out how things work. Imagine playing in the sand and discovering cool stuff about it. You learn the most by touching and trying things, just like little scientists do!
texts.sectioneli5-6-1: Imagine you're out in a big, beautiful park with huge, tall rocks. Even though those giant rocks are cool, two young scientists find something even more exciting: the sand on the ground! They're sitting there, fascinated by how the sand looks and feels after it got wet from rain. This teaches us that being curious about the little things can be just as important as the big things when you're exploring and learning about the world.
texts.sectioneli5-7-0: Imagine you're in a desert, and you see a puddle of water with sand around it. You might wonder: where does the sand come from? Does it come from the rock, or is it the other way around? The sand and water can make fun shapes and patterns. When you see a big rock, you might ask: is it growing from the sand or getting smaller? Science is all about asking these questions. It's like solving mysteries by looking around, asking why things are the way they are, and figuring out how it all works together. It's fun to wonder and learn like this!
texts.sectioneli5-7-1: Science is everywhere, like in puddles, bubbles, and even dancing! It's about being curious, noticing things, and asking questions. You learn science by looking around, thinking about what you see, and sharing what you find with others. Being curious makes science fun and helps you understand the world!
texts.sectioneli5-8-0:
In science and engineering, we do lots of fun things to learn about the world! We start by asking questions, like 'Why is the sky blue?' Then, we try to solve problems, kind of like fixing a broken toy.

We also use models, which are like drawing a picture or making a small version of something big, to help us understand it better. We plan experiments, just like when we try different ways to build the tallest tower with blocks.

Next, we look at our results and see what they tell us, which is like looking at a treasure map to find clues. We use math to help us think, just like counting candy. We explain what we learn and think of new ways to solve problems, like inventing a new game.

Finally, we share what we find with others, like telling friends about a cool bug we saw. This is how scientists and engineers explore and discover amazing things in our world!
texts.sectioneli5-9-0:
Crosscutting Concepts are like a toolbox scientists use to figure out how things work in the world. 

- **Patterns**: Think of how snowflakes all have a pattern—they repeat and look the same.
- **Stability and Change**: Imagine a caterpillar turning into a butterfly—some things stay the same, some things change.
- **Cause and Effect**: Like when you knock over one domino and it makes all the others fall—something causes something else.
- **Scale, Proportion, and Quantity**: This is about how size and time can change how we see things, like using a magnifying glass to see tiny details.
- **Matter and Energy**: This is about how things move and work, like how water flows through a river.
- **Systems**: Imagine a puzzle—all the pieces fit together to make one big picture.
- **Structure and Function**: This is about how the shape of something helps it do its job, like how a bridge's structure lets cars drive over it.
texts.sectioneli5-10-0: Engineering design is like building a cool project with lots of steps. First, you figure out what the problem is and what rules you have to follow. Then, you come up with lots of ideas, like brainstorming in class. Next, you choose the best idea and build a model or prototype to test it out, like making a small version of your project. Finally, you make changes to make it even better. It's all about using creativity and learning from what doesn't work to make the best thing possible!
texts.sectioneli5-10-1:
In engineering, when we want to make something new or see if something works better, we follow some steps. If we're designing, first we figure out what the problem is and what we need to do to fix it. Then, we think of lots of different ways to solve it and pick the best one by testing and improving it.

If we're evaluating, we still figure out the problem and what we need to fix, but instead of coming up with many ways, we look at the options we already have. We find which one works best by checking if it does what we need it to do. So, it's like finding the best way to solve a puzzle with the pieces we have.
texts.sectioneli5-11-0:
Imagine this book is like a big treasure map that helps us learn all about Earth and everything around us!

**Chapter 1: Earth’s Systems**
- *Patterns in Earth’s Features:* How the Earth looks and why some places have mountains and others have valleys.
- *Earth’s Water:* All about the water in oceans, lakes, and rain!
- *Weathering and Erosion:* How rocks get broken down over time into tiny bits.
- *Interactions between Systems:* How different parts of the Earth, like air and water, work together.
- *Impact on Humans:* How all these Earth things affect what we do and how we live.

**Chapter 2: Properties and Changes in Matter**
- *Too Small to See:* Learning about tiny things so small you can’t see them without help.
- *Identifying Substances:* How we know what something is made of.
- *Combining Substances:* What happens when we mix things together.
- *Conservation of Matter:* Understanding that stuff doesn’t just disappear!

**Chapter 3: Cycling of Matter in Earth’s Systems**
- *Building Plants:* How plants grow and where they get their building blocks.
- *Consuming Food:* How we and other animals eat to get energy.
- *Movement of Matter:* How different things move around on Earth.
- *Conserving Resources:* Why it’s important to save and protect what we use every day!
texts.sectioneli5-12-0: This science book for 5th graders is all about learning cool things about nature, like how flowers grow. The picture shows bright and colorful flowers in the sunshine, getting kids excited to explore and discover the wonders of plants and science.
texts.sectioneli5-13-0:
Imagine the Earth as a giant puzzle with different pieces that fit together. These pieces are the geosphere (rocks and soil), hydrosphere (water), atmosphere (air), and biosphere (living things). These pieces talk to each other and work together in many ways. 

For example, weathering and erosion are like the Earth getting a makeover, changing how it looks over time. Sometimes these interactions cause natural events like earthquakes or volcanoes, which can be scary but are a part of how the Earth works. We can't stop these events, but we can find ways to stay safe when they happen.
texts.sectioneli5-13-1: Earth is made up of different parts called systems, like in a big, amazing play. The geosphere is like the stage with rocks and soil. The hydrosphere is the water and ice. The atmosphere is the air. And the biosphere is all the living things, like plants and animals. These parts talk to each other. Sometimes they change things, like making rocks break or rivers move soil. This can lead to big events like volcanoes or earthquakes that can be dangerous to people. While we can't stop these events, we can try to protect ourselves from them, just like putting on a raincoat when it rains.
texts.sectioneli5-15-0: Imagine the Earth as a big puzzle. Where some of the puzzle pieces meet, there are lots of volcanoes and earthquakes. This special area is called the 'Ring of Fire,' and it’s around the Pacific Ocean. The dots you see on the map show where the volcanoes are. It's like the Earth is doing a big, fiery dance in this part of the world!
texts.sectioneli5-15-1: There's a special place in the Pacific Ocean known as the 'Ring of Fire.' It's full of active volcanoes and has lots of earthquakes. When you look at the map with all the dots, you're seeing where those volcanoes are. Observations are like telling what you notice, such as where the dots appear on the map. Wonderings are questions you might have, like why there are so many volcanoes in that area.
texts.sectioneli5-16-0: Volcanoes are like big mountains that sometimes explode! To see where most of them are, you need to look at maps that show them. In some places, there are many volcanoes close together. It's like when toys get left all in one spot; volcanoes often do this in certain parts of the world.
texts.sectioneli5-16-1: Some places on Earth have very few volcanoes, especially where the Earth's tectonic plates don't meet. This means places in the middle of big plates, like some parts of central continents, often have the least volcanoes. Imagine a cookie where the cracks are the busy spots with lots of activity, but the middle might be calm.
texts.sectioneli5-16-2: When we talk about patterns of active volcanoes, we mean where they usually like to be on a map. Imagine drawing a map and noticing that most volcanoes line up like a necklace or a chain. These lines often follow the edges of big land pieces on Earth called tectonic plates, especially around the edges of the Pacific Ocean, which looks like a giant ring.
texts.sectioneli5-17-0: Earth has places where things like volcanoes and earthquakes happen a lot. These spots are usually where big pieces of the Earth, called plates, come together. We can use maps to see where mountains and ocean floor features are to understand these patterns. By looking at where these events happen, we learn about how the Earth works and changes over time.
texts.sectioneli5-17-1: Volcanoes are like big openings in the Earth, kind of like a door. Hot, melted rocks called magma, along with ash and gases, come out of these openings. When this happens, they can change the look of the land around them really quickly. Because of volcanoes, over half of the land we see is made from volcanic rock! They show us that our planet is always moving and changing.
texts.sectioneli5-17-2: Imagine if Earth's crust was like a big chocolate shell, and underneath is a gooey center called magma. This magma gets really hot and melts the rock. Sometimes it needs to get out, just like bubbles escaping from a soda can when you shake it. So, it finds little cracks in the shell and bursts out, which we see as a volcano. Sometimes, these volcanoes are in the ocean and make big underwater mountains. Neat, right?
texts.sectioneli5-17-3: The 'Pacific Ring of Fire' is a place around the edges of the Pacific Ocean where lots of earthquakes and volcanoes happen. Imagine the Earth's outer layer is like a puzzle made of big pieces called plates. These plates can move, and when they do, it can cause the ground to shake (earthquakes) or make volcanoes erupt. This moving and shaking can also help make mountains. It's like the Earth is always changing and moving! 🚀🌋
texts.sectioneli5-17-4:
Our Earth has some amazing patterns! There are places called volcanoes, where really hot, melted rock called magma comes out from the ground. It's so hot that it can turn into rivers of lava!

Now, let's think about how this happens. Deep inside the Earth, the rock is so hot it melts. This melted rock finds cracks in the Earth to escape and that’s how a volcano is made. When a volcano erupts, it can send out lava, ash, and gases.

There's also something called the "Pacific Ring of Fire," which isn't about fire rings, but it's where a lot of earthquakes and volcanoes happen. It's like the Earth has big puzzle pieces called plates that move around slowly. When they bump into each other or pull apart, things like mountains, earthquakes, and volcanoes happen. Imagine snapping a cookie in half—sometimes crunchy stuff happens! That's a bit like what these plates do.
texts.sectioneli5-18-0:
The "Ring of Fire" is like a big circle around the edge of the Pacific Ocean where lots of volcanoes and earthquakes happen. This is because big pieces of the Earth, called tectonic plates, are moving and bumping into each other there. 

When these plates move, hot melted rock called magma can come up and make a volcano. Sometimes, the plates slide past each other, causing the ground to shake, which we call an earthquake.

Also, sometimes the plates move apart, making the ground crack and split. This is like if you pulled apart a graham cracker until it broke. That's why the Ring of Fire has so much cool (and sometimes scary) stuff happening!
texts.sectioneli5-18-1: An earthquake is like when you shake a big table, and everything on it moves and rattles. This happens because the big pieces of Earth's floor, called tectonic plates, slide or bump against each other. When they do, it makes a lot of energy that travels through Earth like ripples in water. Some ripples move along the ground where we stand (surface waves), while others go deep inside the Earth (body waves). These waves make the ground shake and can change how the land looks.
texts.sectioneli5-19-0: Earthquakes are like when the Earth shakes or wiggles because giant puzzle pieces called tectonic plates are moving around. Sometimes these plates push together and make big bumps called mountains. Even if we don’t see anything on top, the ground can still move underneath us quietly. When earthquakes happen in the ocean, they can cause giant waves called tsunamis that splash onto the land.
texts.sectioneli5-19-1:
So, under the ocean, there are big pieces of Earth called plates. These plates sometimes move away from each other, like pieces of a puzzle getting pulled apart. When this happens, hot, gooey stuff called lava comes up from below, cools down, and makes new ground, which is like a new floor under the ocean. This is how a long chain of mountains forms under the sea!

Sometimes, as the plates move apart, it can cause little shakes called earthquakes. Most of these mountain chains are deep in the ocean, but there's a place called Iceland where you can see them on land. It's a part of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. In the picture you see, there's a valley in Iceland that's part of this ridge!
texts.sectioneli5-20-0: Imagine the Earth like a big puzzle with pieces called tectonic plates. Sometimes these pieces bump into each other, and that can make a rumble called an earthquake. The places where these pieces meet are shown by dark lines. The little red dots are volcanoes, and many of them are along these lines, especially in a special area called the "Ring of Fire." In the future, because of all this moving and shaking, we might see new mountains or islands forming!
texts.sectioneli5-21-0:
Imagine the Earth is like a giant sandcastle. Over time, two big things can change it. 

First, think of rain and wind as little helpers that slowly wash or blow away parts of the sandcastle. This is called erosion. 

Second, sometimes the sandcastle shakes or cracks a bit, like when someone walks by. This is similar to earthquakes, which can quickly change how the Earth looks by moving it around. 

Both of these are natural changes that happen to the Earth and are just like changes that can happen to your sandcastle!
texts.sectioneli5-23-0: Imagine you have a big bucket of water. Most of the water in it, about 97 out of every 100 drops, is salty, like the ocean, and not good to drink. Only 3 out of those 100 drops are freshwater, the kind we drink. This freshwater is mostly frozen in ice or deep underground, not in lakes or rivers.
texts.sectioneli5-23-1: We have a lot of water on Earth, and most of it is salty, like the water in the ocean. There's only a tiny bit that's fresh, like what we drink from rivers and lakes. This makes us think about why there's so much salty water and only a little fresh water. We can ask questions like, 'Why is it mostly salty?' or 'What do we do with all the salty water?' These are our observations and wonderings!
texts.sectioneli5-24-0: On Earth, most of the water is salty, like in the oceans. Only a tiny bit of it is fresh and on the surface, like in lakes and rivers, that we can easily use. What's surprising is how little of that fresh water there is compared to all the water on Earth.
texts.sectioneli5-25-0: Earth has water almost everywhere, like in the oceans, rivers, and even in the air! Most of this water is salty, like in the ocean, but some is fresh, like in rivers and lakes. We can use math to help us figure out how much salty and fresh water there is by counting or drawing pictures. This helps us understand where all the water is on Earth.
texts.sectioneli5-25-1: Water on Earth is found almost everywhere! It's in the air we breathe, in the clouds up high, in rivers and oceans, and frozen like ice. It's in plants and inside living things like us, and even hidden underground. Imagine water drops are like little explorers traveling all over the Earth!
texts.sectioneli5-25-2: Water on Earth is almost everywhere! It's in the clouds, oceans, rivers, ice, plants, animals, and even inside the ground. We can use math to figure out how much water there is in these places and see how much saltwater and freshwater we have. This helps us understand where water is and how important it is for everything on Earth.
texts.sectioneli5-26-0:
Imagine the Earth is a giant cup of water. Most of that cup, about 97%, is super salty ocean water, which we can't drink. Only a tiny sip, around 2.5%, is freshwater, which is what we need to live. 

Almost all of the freshwater is frozen like ice cubes or hidden underground. When we look at the water that's not frozen or hidden, we find it mostly in lakes. Rivers, although small like tiny streams, are really important because most of our drinking water comes from them! So, even though they are small, rivers are really useful to us.
texts.sectioneli5-26-1: Our planet, Earth, is like a big, wet marble! About 71 out of every 100 parts of the Earth's surface is covered in water. Most of this water, almost all of it, is found in the oceans, which are salty. Oceans have 96 out of every 100 parts of Earth's water. The rest is mostly frozen in ice or buried underground, and only a tiny bit is the fresh water we need to drink and use every day.
texts.sectioneli5-27-0: Water isn't just in places like rivers or lakes. A lot of water is actually hidden underground. Some of the water flows from rain into the ground and becomes 'groundwater.' This underground water fills up spaces in soil and rocks and keeps rivers full by slowly seeping back into them. We use this groundwater along with water from rivers and lakes to drink and water plants, especially in places where it's really dry.
texts.sectioneli5-27-1: There's lots of water under the ground! More than what we see on the rivers and lakes. Rainwater seeps into the earth and fills up spaces called aquifers, which are like big underground water bottles. This groundwater slowly moves and helps keep rivers full, even when it's not raining. We use this underground water to help people and plants, especially in places where there's not much rain.
texts.sectioneli5-27-2: We use two types of water: surface water, like from lakes and rivers, and groundwater, which is hidden in the ground. In 2010, people in the United States used a lot of both kinds every day. Surface water gives us drinking water and helps grow food. Groundwater helps keep rivers and lakes full and gives water to people in dry places, like deserts. It's important even though we can't see it.
texts.sectioneli5-28-0: Imagine Earth has a giant glass of water. Most of that water, about 97 out of 100 parts, is salty and found in the ocean, just like how sea water tastes salty. Only a tiny part, 3 out of 100, is freshwater, which we need for drinking. This freshwater is mostly frozen in icecaps or underground. A very small part of it is found in lakes, rivers, and swamps, which we use a lot.
texts.sectioneli5-28-1: Most of the water on Earth is salty, like in the oceans. But we can find freshwater in just a few places. Here are three places where freshwater is found: in icecaps and glaciers, underground, and in lakes and rivers. Surface water is made up of lakes, rivers, and swamps. These places help give us the water that we can use.
texts.sectioneli5-29-0: For your final task, you're going to make a bar graph. Think of a bar graph like a picture that compares how much saltwater and freshwater we have on Earth. Saltwater is like the ocean, and freshwater is like the water in lakes and rivers. You'll draw two bars: one to show how much saltwater there is, and another to show how much freshwater. This helps us see which one we have more of!
texts.sectioneli5-30-0: Imagine you're walking in a big garden full of bright, colorful flowers. The sun is shining brightly, and the flowers are reaching up to it. This is like a picture showing how flowers need sunlight to grow and be healthy. The sunlight helps them make their food, which is a magical science process we learn about in 5th-grade science!
texts.sectioneli5-31-0: Imagine a sidewalk that's cracked. This happens because of weathering and erosion. Weathering is like when rain, sun, or wind slowly wears something down. Erosion is when little pieces get moved away. Look at the cracks in the sidewalk—it’s like the earth is slowly breaking and moving it! What do you think could happen next? What else might cause the cracks?

texts.easyread-text-8-0: Science and engineering practices are the ways scientists and engineers learn about the world and solve problems. They ask questions, make plans, do experiments, and try to fix things when they don't work right.
texts.easyread-text-8-1: Scientists use special methods to study and understand nature.
texts.easyread-text-8-2: Learning to ask questions and understanding problems are important skills. Asking questions helps us learn and find answers. Defining problems means we find out what the problem is, so we can fix it.
texts.easyread-text-8-3: We make small copies of things to understand or solve problems. We use these small copies, called models, to help us learn.

texts.easyread-text-9-0: Crosscutting concepts are ideas that help us see connections and solve problems in different subjects.
texts.easyread-text-9-1: Scientists use Crosscutting Concepts to understand nature.
texts.easyread-text-9-3: Patterns are things that repeat over and over. Like stripes on a shirt or the days of the week. They help us know what comes next.
texts.easyread-text-9-4: Things or events often happen in the same way many times.
texts.easyread-text-9-5: Stability means things staying the same. Change means things become different.
texts.easyread-text-9-6: Things can change or stay the same over time. It depends on different reasons.
texts.easyread-text-9-7: Cause means why something happens. Effect is what happens because of it.
texts.easyread-text-9-8: Things happen because of simple or many reasons.
texts.easyread-text-9-9: Scale is the size of one thing compared to another. Proportion is how parts of something fit together. Quantity is how much there is of something.
texts.easyread-text-9-10: Different ways of measuring size and time can change how a system works and how we look at things.
texts.easyread-text-9-11: Everything around us is stuff called matter, like your toys, water, and the air. Energy is what makes things move or work, like when you run or a light turns on.
texts.easyread-text-9-12: Paying attention to how energy and matter move in and out of things helps us understand how they work.

texts.easyread-text-10-0: Engineering design means solving problems and making new things. Engineers think of ideas, make plans, try them out, and fix them until they work.
texts.easyread-text-10-1: Engineering is making and improving things. We try new ideas, learn from them, and make changes to make things better.
texts.easyread-text-10-3: We need to see what the problem is and decide what things can be done and what things cannot be done.
texts.easyread-text-10-4: Thinking of new ways to fix the problem.
texts.easyread-text-10-5: Engineers work with others and think of new ideas to solve problems.
texts.easyread-text-10-6: To find the best design solution, look at the options and see which ones follow the rules and fit within the limits.
texts.easyread-text-10-7: Make and try out the first models.
texts.easyread-text-10-8: The engineer looks at how well the models are working and if they are doing what they are supposed to do.
texts.easyread-text-10-9: Give ideas to make the first model better.
texts.easyread-text-10-10: In science classes, you learn and do two main kinds of engineering activities.
texts.easyread-text-10-11: When you design something, you start by understanding the problem. Then, you think of many ways to solve it. Finally, you choose the best idea by testing and making it better.
texts.easyread-text-10-12: The design process means finding the problem, figuring out what you need to do and what you can't do, and making the best solution.
texts.easyread-text-10-13: We don't need to think of new solutions because we already have many choices.
texts.easyread-text-10-14: We choose the best solution by seeing which one meets the needs and rules.

texts.easyread-text-11-1: This chapter is about Earth's systems. It tells us how the land, water, and air of Earth work together. It will help us understand how the Earth keeps us alive and healthy.
texts.easyread-text-11-3: We learn about the shapes and forms we see in things on Earth.
texts.easyread-text-11-5: The Earth's water includes oceans, lakes, rivers, and rain. All of these are important for life.
texts.easyread-text-11-7: Weathering is when rocks break into smaller pieces. Erosion is when wind or water move those pieces to a new place.
texts.easyread-text-11-9: Different systems work together like parts of a big machine. They help each other to do jobs.
texts.easyread-text-11-13: This chapter talks about what things are made of and how they can change. We will learn about why things are different and how they can change from one thing to another.
texts.easyread-text-11-15: Some things are so tiny we can't see them without a microscope, like cells or germs.
texts.easyread-text-11-17: We can find out what something is by looking at it, smelling it, or touching it. We use our senses to know if something is soft, hard, sticky, or has a smell.
texts.easyread-text-11-19: Mixing different things together is called combining substances.
texts.easyread-text-11-21: Things don't disappear or appear out of nowhere; they just change into different things. For example, when you melt an ice cube, it turns into water. The ice is still there, but now it's in a different form.
texts.easyread-text-11-23: Chapter 3 is about how things like water and nutrients move around in nature.
texts.easyread-text-11-25: We will learn about how plants grow and what they need to grow.
texts.easyread-text-11-29: This part talks about how things move or change, like water, air, and rocks.
texts.easyread-text-11-31: We should save things like water and electricity to protect the earth. It is important to use only what we need so that resources last longer.

texts.easyread-text-17-1: Look at the information to find and explain how the features on Earth's surface are arranged.

texts.easyread-text-17-6: Volcanoes are openings in the Earth's surface where lava comes out. Earthquakes happen when the ground shakes. The ocean floor is the bottom part of the ocean water.
texts.easyread-text-17-7: A volcano is a mountain with a hole at the top. Sometimes, it explodes with lava and ash. Volcanoes can be very dangerous.
texts.easyread-text-17-8: A volcano is a hole in the Earth's surface where hot, melted rock, ash, and gases come out.
texts.easyread-text-17-9: Volcanoes can change the Earth's surface quickly.
texts.easyread-text-17-10: Over half of Earth is covered with volcanic rock.

texts.easyread-text-17-15: Some volcanoes have small eruptions with lava like a river. Other volcanoes have bigger eruptions.
texts.easyread-text-17-16: Volcanoes can explode under the water and make big mountains in the ocean.

texts.easyread-text-17-19: Earth's surface has big pieces called plates.

texts.easyread-text-17-22: The Ring of Fire is a big line of volcanoes around the Pacific Ocean. It's called the Ring of Fire because there are lots of volcanoes and earthquakes there. It happens because the ground underneath is moving.
texts.easyread-text-17-23: The Earth's surface is made of big pieces called plates. These plates move very slowly. Sometimes they crash into each other or move apart. This movement can cause earthquakes and make mountains.
texts.easyread-text-18-0: The Ring of Fire has many volcanoes and earthquakes because big pieces of the Earth's surface, called tectonic plates, move a lot there.
texts.easyread-text-18-1: In the Ring of Fire, the ground plates push over each other.
texts.easyread-text-18-2: Hot liquid rock under Earth's ground makes volcanoes happen.
texts.easyread-text-18-3: The Pacific Plate and the North American Plate touch each other. They slide past each other sideways.
texts.easyread-text-18-4: Some places in the Earth's crust can cause many earthquakes because they stretch and then snap back.
texts.easyread-text-18-5: Pieces of the Earth's surface, called plates, can sometimes pull apart from each other, even on the same continent.
texts.easyread-text-18-6: Big pieces of land start to move away from each other.
texts.easyread-text-18-7: The Earth's crust becomes thin, then it breaks, and splits apart.
texts.easyread-text-18-8: When the ground shakes, we call it an earthquake. It happens when big rocks under the earth move suddenly. This movement makes the ground shake.
texts.easyread-text-18-9: Earthquakes happen when the big pieces of land under the ground move suddenly. This makes the ground shake.
texts.easyread-text-18-10: Earthquakes can make the land look very different quickly.
texts.easyread-text-18-11: Strong forces inside the Earth push and make pressure. This pressure comes out in waves along a crack.
texts.easyread-text-18-12: Pieces of Earth's crust move and make waves.
texts.easyread-text-18-13: Some waves are called surface waves because they move on the Earth's surface.
texts.easyread-text-18-14: Body waves are waves that go inside the Earth.
texts.easyread-text-18-15: In an earthquake, waves inside the ground make it shake quickly.
texts.easyread-text-18-16: Surface waves cause things to happen on the surface.
texts.easyread-text-19-0: Rolling motions can cause a lot of damage.
texts.easyread-text-19-1: Earthquakes can change the shape of the land.
texts.easyread-text-19-2: Mountains can grow when big pieces of Earth's crust push together during an earthquake.
texts.easyread-text-19-3: During an earthquake, a crack in the ground might move deep down, and you can't see it on top of the ground.
texts.easyread-text-19-4: An earthquake in the ocean can make a big wave called a tsunami.
texts.easyread-text-19-5: The ocean floor is the bottom of the sea. It is the land under the water where fish and plants live.
texts.easyread-text-19-6: In the ocean, the ground moves apart and hot melted rock, called lava, comes up. This makes volcanoes.
texts.easyread-text-19-7: Lava erupts and makes the ocean floor spread by pushing it outward and forming new crust.
texts.easyread-text-19-8: There are underwater mountains in the ocean because the Earth's plates move apart, and this creates mountains called ridges.
texts.easyread-text-19-9: When the big pieces of land under us move away from each other, they can make the ground shake. This shaking is called an earthquake.
texts.easyread-text-19-10: Most mid-ocean ridges are found deep under the sea.
texts.easyread-text-19-11: Iceland is on a big ocean ridge in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean.
texts.easyread-text-19-12: The Mid Atlantic Ridge is a big mountain under the ocean. People can learn about it for free.
texts.easyread-text-19-13: There is a big crack in the ground in Iceland called a rift valley. It is part of a large mountain range under the ocean called the Mid-Atlantic Ridge.

texts.easyread-text-20-1: Volcanoes that can erupt are called active volcanoes. They sit on big pieces of the Earth's crust called tectonic plates. Many active volcanoes are around the Pacific Ocean, in a place called the "Ring of Fire."

texts.easyread-text-20-6: We know that earthquakes happen a lot where two pieces of the Earth's surface, called plates, meet. These places are called plate boundaries. The plates can move and bump into each other, making the ground shake.
texts.easyread-text-20-7: Volcanoes are mountains that have hot, melted rocks inside. When they explode, it's called an eruption. Earthquakes make the ground shake. Both happen because the Earth's surface moves.
texts.easyread-text-20-8: In the future, the land and seas on Earth might change. Volcanoes can make new land, and water might wear away rocks and dirt. Scientists study these changes to understand what might happen.
